study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of staged rehabilitation training, including walking, on inflammatory factors, red blood cell distribution, and quality of life in patients after cardiac valve replacement.
results_summary: Staged rehabilitation training significantly reduced inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6, CRP) and improved red blood cell distribution (RDW), quality of life (WHOQOL-BREF), and walking performance (6MWD) compared to conventional care, with no difference in adverse events.
population_specificity: 140 patients who underwent cardiac valve replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high risk of sarcopenia, assessed using the SARC-F questionnaire (which includes assistance in walking as an item), affects in-hospital mortality in older patients with pulmonary tuberculosis.
results_summary: The study found that a high risk of sarcopenia, particularly the need for assistance in walking and rising from a chair, was a significant risk factor for in-hospital mortality in older patients with pulmonary tuberculosis.
population_specificity: Older patients (aged ≥65 years) with active pulmonary tuberculosis requiring inpatient treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a multicomponent intervention (including exercise, dietary advice, and oral nutritional supplementation) on nutritional status, body composition, physical function, and quality of life in older adults at risk of malnutrition.
results_summary: The study found that the multicomponent intervention improved nutritional status and body composition, with the research group (including ONS) showing increases in fat-free mass and appendicular skeletal muscle mass. However, there were no significant between-group differences in physical function, quality of life, or most secondary outcomes, though the 6-minute walking distance slightly favored the research group.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 60+) with malnutrition or at risk of malnutrition in six nursing homes in China.
effective_dosage: ONS (244 kcal, 9.8g protein, 9.6g fat per serving) twice daily between meals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate health-related quality of life, physical functioning, fatigue, and cognitive outcomes in COVID-19 survivors who received invasive mechanical ventilation, using the 6-minute walking test as a measure of physical function.
results_summary: The study found that 18 months post-discharge, COVID-19 survivors had moderate reductions in health-related quality of life and severe reductions in physical functioning, with fatigue more prevalent in younger patients and females. Cognitive impairment was present but at a low frequency.
population_specificity: COVID-19 survivors who required invasive mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure, with an average age of 60 ± 10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using the Ultrasound Sarcopenia Index (USI) to assess muscle mass in elderly patients with proximal femoral fractures and compare outcomes between independent walkers and those requiring walking aids.
results_summary: The study found that the USI was significantly higher in patients who walked independently compared to those requiring walking aids, suggesting that USI may help diagnose sarcopenia when combined with other strength and function measures.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (aged >65 years) hospitalized for proximal femoral traumatic fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of interactive boxing-cycling versus stationary cycling in improving frailty and activity limitations in frail and prefrail older adults.
results_summary: Both cycling methods significantly improved frailty scores, with interactive boxing-cycling showing greater effectiveness in reversing muscle weakness and improving arm curl performance compared to stationary cycling. However, it was not superior to stationary cycling in overall frailty improvement.
population_specificity: Frail and prefrail older adults meeting at least one frailty phenotype criterion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the use of induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells to study hereditary spastic paraplegias (HSPs) and explore potential therapeutic approaches.
results_summary: The review found that patient-derived iPS cells can reliably model HSP in vitro, enabling discoveries through immunological and -omics approaches and serving as a platform for drug screening. However, current therapeutic approaches remain symptomatic, with no cure available.
population_specificity: Patients with hereditary spastic paraplegias (HSPs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of pragmatic physical activity interventions (Walking Away and Walking Away Plus) in reducing the risk of type 2 diabetes in a high-risk multiethnic population.
results_summary: Neither Walking Away nor Walking Away Plus was cost-effective at the £20,000 per QALY threshold. However, the study suggested that interventions achieving a sustained increase of 500 steps per day could be cost-effective.
population_specificity: Multiethnic population at high risk of type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate compliance with physical activity recommendations in people with severe haemophilia over a 1-year period using activity wristbands and to assess the effect of self-monitoring on clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that participants averaged 10,379 steps per day, with 63% reaching the 10,000-step goal at follow-up. Self-monitoring improved physical health-related quality of life and increased time spent in moderate-intensity physical activity.
population_specificity: 27 adults with severe haemophilia undergoing prophylactic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a multidisciplinary team (MDT) approach on clinical outcomes, including healing and amputation rates, in patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
results_summary: Patients managed by an MDT had better outcomes in terms of healing, minor and major amputation, and survival compared to those managed using other approaches. No data were found on quality of life, returning-to-walking, or emergency admissions.
population_specificity: Patients with active diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of pentosan polysulfate sodium (PPS) as a potential disease-modifying treatment for musculoskeletal symptoms and joint inflammation in MPS I patients previously treated with ERT and/or HSCT.
results_summary: PPS was well tolerated with no serious adverse events, reduced GAG fragments and cartilage degradation biomarkers, and improved pain and physical function outcomes, including walking distance.
population_specificity: Four subjects with MPS I aged 14-19 years, previously treated with ERT and/or HSCT.
effective_dosage: 0.75 mg/kg or 1.5 mg/kg via subcutaneous injections weekly for 12 weeks, then every 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of liraglutide on peripheral perfusion (measured via TcPo2) in individuals with type 2 diabetes and peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Liraglutide significantly improved peripheral perfusion (TcPo2) compared to conventional treatment, with 89% of the liraglutide group achieving a 10% increase in TcPo2 versus 46% in the control group. It also reduced inflammation (C-reactive protein), improved kidney function (urinary albumin to creatinine ratio), and increased 6-minute walking distance.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes, PAD, and baseline TcPo2 between 30-49 mm Hg (mean age 67.5 years, 78% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a home-based rehabilitation exercise program, including walking, for improving effort tolerance in post-COVID-19 patients with residual disability after inpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that the home-based exercise program with teleconsultation significantly improved effort tolerance, but only in participants with severe effort intolerance at baseline. No significant differences were observed between the intervention and control groups overall after 2 months.
population_specificity: Post-COVID-19 patients (mean age 67.1 years, 72% male) with residual effort intolerance or hypoxia despite prior inpatient rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Exercises were divided into 4 intensity levels, progressing from low (walking, free-body exercises) to high (speed walking with a pedometer, cycle ergometer). Frequency included bi-weekly physiotherapist video calls.
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 2 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare lower limb kinematic and kinetic differences during walking between individuals with stage 1 and stage 2 posterior tibialis tendon dysfunction (PTTD) and healthy controls.
results_summary: PTTD1 showed minimal biomechanical differences compared to controls, while PTTD2 exhibited significant differences, including greater ankle plantarflexion and eversion, midfoot dorsiflexion and inversion, and altered knee and hip biomechanics in late stance. The study highlights progressive biomechanical deficits as PTTD advances from stage 1 to stage 2.
population_specificity: Individuals with stage 1 PTTD (n=16), stage 2 PTTD (n=11), and healthy controls (n=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and synthesize the measurement properties (reliability, validity, responsiveness) of the backward walk test in people with balance and mobility deficits.
results_summary: The backward walk test demonstrated good interrater and intrarater reliability, as well as moderate to good concurrent validity across various patient populations. The 3-meter backward walk time and speed were identified as useful outcome measures for assessing balance and mobility in clinical practice.
population_specificity: Patients with cerebral palsy, stroke, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, fibromyalgia, hip and knee arthroplasty, dementia, and community-dwelling older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of minimally invasive dorsal cheilectomy (MIDC) with first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) arthroscopy in improving outcomes for patients with Hallux Rigidus (HR) over a minimum 1-year follow-up.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in range of motion, pain scores, and quality-of-life metrics (MOXFQ and EQ-5D-5L) post-intervention, with low complication and revision rates. These results suggest MIDC with first MTP arthroscopy is effective for early-stage HR.
population_specificity: Adult patients with Coughlin and Shurnass Grade 0-3 Hallux Rigidus.
study_duration: Average follow-up of 16.5 months (range: 12 to 26.2 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a postoperative exercise program, including walking, improves functional recovery in lung cancer patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
results_summary: The exercise group showed significantly better maximal oxygen consumption and walking distance in the 6-minute walk test compared to the control group, though other pulmonary function and quality-of-life measures did not reach statistical significance.
population_specificity: Lung cancer patients comorbid with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (n=84).
effective_dosage: 24 training sessions (specific walking dosage not detailed).
study_duration: 1 week of standard rehabilitation followed by exercise intervention (total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flexible intramedullary nailing (FIN) is effective for managing unstable femur fractures in children.
results_summary: The study found that FIN with a single walking spica cast was effective, with excellent results in 61.92% of patients and satisfactory results in 32.61%. Locked Ender's nail was associated with the least reoperation, malunion, and limb length discrepancy rates.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with unstable femur fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of exercise (including brisk walking) and dietary intervention on physical fitness, quality of life, and immune response in people living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in stress burnout, physical efficiency index, reaction speed, grip strength, physical satisfaction, and exercise motivation in the intervention group. However, no significant changes were observed in body composition.
population_specificity: 25 male PLWHA with no recent exercise or nutritional supplement habits.
effective_dosage: 45 minutes of brisk walking or running (60-80% HRmax) 4 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of low-intensity aerobic exercise with blood flow restriction (LI-AE-BFR) versus high-intensity interval exercise (HIIE) on perceptual and physiological responses during walking.
results_summary: The study found that high-intensity interval exercise (HIIE) led to greater increases in blood lactate concentrations compared to low-intensity aerobic exercise with blood flow restriction (LI-AE-BFR). Both interventions were assessed for perceptual responses (exertion, pain, affective response) and physiological measures (heart rate, muscle fatigue).
population_specificity: Ten healthy untrained men (average age 25.6 years, BMI 24.95 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: HIIE: 10 one-minute intervals at 80% peak running velocity; LI-AE-BFR: 20 minutes continuous walking at 40% peak running velocity with blood flow restriction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of hearing loss and balance disorders on elderly individuals, focusing on early detection, mitigation, and advocacy for healthy aging.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in hearing, balance, cognition, and overall well-being among elderly individuals with untreated and treated hearing/balance disorders, with the treated group (group C) showing the worst outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals over 55 years old, divided into groups based on hearing and balance status (normal, detected but untreated, detected and treated).
study_duration: Follow-up every year or every 2 years (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a GDM subsidy program in promoting healthier lifestyles, including increased walking, among pregnant women in rural China.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a healthier lifestyle, with more walking minutes compared to the control group, alongside improved maternal and neonatal health outcomes.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in 24-28 weeks' gestation in rural China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between iron deficiency markers (anaemia, ferritin, TSAT) and the response to intravenous iron (ferric derisomaltose) in heart failure patients, including effects on haemoglobin, quality of life (MLwHF score), and walking distance (6-minute walk test).
results_summary: Intravenous iron (FDI) increased haemoglobin more in patients with lower baseline TSAT, ferritin, or more severe anaemia. MLwHF scores improved slightly in more anaemic patients, but walking distance did not differ significantly between FDI and control groups. Patients with anaemia or TSAT < 20% (especially with ferritin ≥100 µg/L) showed higher event rates and potential benefit from FDI, though not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 1137 heart failure patients with ejection fraction ≤ 45% and either serum ferritin < 100 µg/L or TSAT < 20%.
effective_dosage: Intravenous ferric derisomaltose (specific dosage not stated in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors related to changes in walking performance in individuals 3 months after a stroke or TIA.
results_summary: Younger age, male sex, lower BMI, shorter baseline 6-minute walk test, and possibly no comorbidity were associated with improved walking performance at 3 months post-stroke or TIA. The regression model explained 36% of the variance in walking performance changes.
population_specificity: 79 individuals (64±10 years, 37% women) acutely hospitalized due to stroke or TIA.
effective_dosage: Daily mobile phone text messages with instructions for outdoor walking, functional leg exercises, step counting, and training diaries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the immediate and longer-term effects of a robotic exoskeleton device (EXOD) on gait in individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: No significant immediate impact of EXOD usage on gait measures was found, and post-intervention differences in gait speed and secondary outcomes were not significant between the intervention and control groups. Participants with greater disease severity showed some improvement in stride length during unassisted walking after the intervention.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (Hoehn and Yahr stages 1-3).
effective_dosage: Supervised in-home and community training with the EXOD twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of physical interventions, including walking, in enhancing return-to-work (RTW) rates for people with cancer compared to usual care.
results_summary: Physical interventions, including walking, likely increase RTW rates compared to usual care, with moderate-certainty evidence. However, these interventions may result in little to no difference in quality of life.
population_specificity: People with cancer, primarily breast cancer (9 RCTs) or prostate cancer (2 RCTs), in high-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the strength of evidence supporting the use of calcitonin (CT) in treating lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), particularly its effects on walking distance and other outcomes.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that CT did not significantly improve walking distance, VAS, or ODI in patients with LSS, indicating no benefit from CT treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify distinguishing motor and cognitive features to disentangle the roles of the posterior parietal cortex (PPC) and cerebellum in gait and body schema representation.
results_summary: Inhibitory stimulation of PPC and cerebellum increased instability during balance tasks, with PPC inhibition affecting eyes-closed conditions and cerebellar inhibition impacting both eyes-open and eyes-closed conditions. Gait variability and distance estimation parameters differed between the two groups, suggesting these measures could help differentiate cerebellar and PPC sensorimotor deficits.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the fusion rates and clinical outcomes of facet fusion using cortical bone trajectory screws (CBT-FF) versus percutaneous pedicle screws (PPS-FF) in patients with degenerative lumbar spondylolisthesis, including walking ability.
results_summary: Both CBT-FF and PPS-FF showed similar fusion rates (91.2% vs. 90.1%) and clinical outcomes, including walking ability (84.7% vs. 89.3% therapeutic effectiveness). No significant differences were observed in other measures like pain scores or revision surgery rates, though CBT-FF had less intraoperative blood loss.
population_specificity: Patients with single-level degenerative lumbar spondylolisthesis (68 in CBT-FF group, 143 in PPS-FF group).
study_duration: Follow-up of at least 1 year postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and potential clinical benefits of the PAHcare™ digital platform for managing pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), including its impact on Health-Related Quality of Life (HRQoL) and clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Minimal changes in HRQoL and clinical outcomes were observed over 6 months, but patient satisfaction and engagement with the platform were high, with 92.4% active usage in the first month and 70% retention rates. The platform showed no significant changes in healthcare resource utilization or safety concerns.
population_specificity: 53 patients diagnosed with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of noninvasive brain stimulation (tDCS or TMS) on functional locomotion, particularly gait parameters, in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in gait speed or cadence between NIBS and control groups, but a statistically significant improvement in stride length, especially when NIBS was applied in multiple sessions alongside motor rehabilitation.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining mirror visual feedback (MVF) with functional electrical stimulation (FES) improves limb function, fine motor skills, and balance in hemiplegic patients after acute cerebral infarction (ACI) compared to FES alone.
results_summary: The study found that MVF combined with FES significantly improved walking parameters, motor function (FMA score), balance (Berg score, fall index), and reduced Time-Up-Go Time (TUGT) compared to FES alone, with statistically significant results (P = .000).
population_specificity: 106 post-ACI hemiplegic patients, split into two groups of 53 each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dry needling (DN) could improve gait parameters, such as walking speed and hip motion, in individuals with Piriformis Muscle Syndrome (PMS).
results_summary: The study found that DN significantly improved peak hip extension during walking in individuals with PMS, with marginal improvements in peak hip flexion compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Thirty-two individuals diagnosed with Piriformis Muscle Syndrome (PMS).
effective_dosage: Three sessions of dry needling (DN) of the piriformis muscle.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to be short-term (duration of three DN sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between early mobilization (walking training within 14 days) and functional outcomes in patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (aSAH).
results_summary: The study found that early mobilization (walking training within 14 days of aSAH onset) was associated with a significantly higher proportion of favorable functional outcomes (81.1% vs. 52.5%) compared to delayed mobilization. The risk difference was 28.7%, with a statistically significant p-value < 0.001.
population_specificity: Patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (aSAH) in Japan who received physical therapy with or without occupational therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking training initiated within 14 days vs. after 14 days).
study_duration: Not specified (retrospective study covering April 2014 to March 2019).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine current mobilisation routines after abdominal and cardiothoracic surgery and identify factors associated with early postoperative mobilisation (within 6 hours).
results_summary: 52% of patients were mobilised within 6 hours post-surgery, with 96% mobilised within 24 hours. Factors like daytime arrival at recovery, shorter anaesthesia duration, and lower ASA classification increased the likelihood of early mobilisation.
population_specificity: 1492 adult patients undergoing abdominal and cardiothoracic surgery with anaesthesia duration >2 hours in 18 Swedish hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence of walking and cognitive fatigability and their associated clinical characteristics in people with progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS).
results_summary: The study found that 51% of participants exhibited walking fatigability, associated with higher disability and worse physical function, while 66% showed cognitive fatigability, though it lacked strong associations with clinical or physical functions. The magnitude of walking and cognitive fatigability were not related.
population_specificity: People with progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS), aged 25-65, with cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of conjunctival microvascular changes in predicting outcomes for SLE patients with PAH, using parameters like 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) as a functional measure.
results_summary: The study found that conjunctival microvascular density (VD) and microvascular flow index (MFI) correlated with 6MWD, WHO-FC, and NT-proBNP, suggesting these eye signs could predict therapeutic efficacy and prognosis in SLE-PAH patients. Improved patients had higher VD and MFI, indicating better cardiopulmonary function.
population_specificity: 29 SLE patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
effective_dosage: Not specified (6MWD was measured, not prescribed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of Chinese herbal medicine in treating sarcopenia, including its impact on muscle mass, strength, and function.
results_summary: The study found that Chinese herbal medicine improved total efficiency, muscle mass, grip strength, and walking speed in sarcopenia patients, suggesting it has an ameliorating effect either alone or combined with conventional treatment.
population_specificity: Aging individuals with sarcopenia (N=1440 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of voluntary walking interventions on walking performance in persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).
results_summary: Walking interventions improved walking performance in short and long distance walk tests, with effect sizes ranging from -0.21 to -0.72 for walking time and 0.27 to 0.72 for walking distance. The interventions were well-attended, had low dropout rates, and few adverse events.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of action observation on walking ability and brain activity in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The action observation group showed significant improvements in brain asymmetry at alpha frequency, stance phase percentage, and step length, but no significant correlations were found between brain activity changes and functional improvements, likely due to small sample size.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=14)
effective_dosage: 12 sessions of 12 min observational training and 40 min occupational therapy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intrapersonal or interpersonal behavior change strategies, combined with the Otago Exercise Program and a wearable activity monitor, could help older adults sustain increases in physical activity.
results_summary: Participants receiving interventions with interpersonal behavior change strategies showed significant increases in total physical activity at 1 week, 6 months, and 12 months post-intervention, while intrapersonal strategies did not yield significant changes. The effects of interpersonal strategies were sustained over time without significant interactions with intrapersonal strategies.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 70+ with physical activity levels below national guidelines (mean age 77.4 years; 77.7% women).
effective_dosage: Otago Exercise Program (17 strength and balance exercises plus walking, performed 3 times per week).
study_duration: 8 weekly small-group meetings, with follow-up assessments at 1 week, 6 months, and 12 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether forced-rate aerobic exercise (FE) paired with upper extremity repetitive task practice (RTP) improves motor recovery post-stroke compared to RTP alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between the FE + RTP and RTP-only groups in primary motor recovery outcomes, but the FE + RTP group showed greater improvement in walking capacity (6MWT).
population_specificity: Individuals ≥6 months post-stroke with upper extremity hemiparesis.
effective_dosage: 45 minutes of FE (5-minute warm-up, 35-minute main set, 5-minute cool down) followed by 45 minutes of RTP, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and histopathological features of phosphaturic mesenchymal tumors (PMTs) and their impact on symptoms, including difficulty in walking.
results_summary: The study found that PMTs caused symptoms such as difficulty in walking, bone pain, and weakness. Post-resection, patients experienced complete resolution of symptoms with no recurrence or metastasis.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with phosphaturic mesenchymal tumors (10 cases, average age 40 years, M:F ratio 4:1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of robotic arm-assisted total knee arthroplasty (raTKA) versus conventional manual TKA (cmTKA) in terms of postoperative pain, function, and alignment accuracy.
results_summary: The study found that raTKA provided better functional recovery (improved active range of motion and flexion range when walking) and more accurate prosthesis positioning compared to cmTKA, though pain levels and other metrics were similar between groups.
population_specificity: 60 patients undergoing primary unilateral total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the incidence of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) after COVID-19 vaccination and describe its clinical characteristics and potential confounders.
results_summary: The study found that GBS cases occurred after COVID-19 vaccination, particularly with AstraZeneca and Pfizer vaccines, with most patients surviving but experiencing compromised ambulation. A higher risk of GBS complications was associated with symptom onset later than 12-13 days post-vaccination.
population_specificity: Cases of Guillain-Barré Syndrome following COVID-19 vaccination (175 cases from 103 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aerobic exercise (including walking) is more effective for stroke rehabilitation in patients less than 3 months post-stroke compared to those more than 3 months post-stroke.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise improved cognitive ability, walking capacity, VO2peak, and brain-derived neurotrophic factor in stroke patients, with greater benefits observed in those within 3 months post-stroke.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (both <3 months and >3 months post-stroke)
effective_dosage: High-intensity or moderate-intensity aerobic training (specific amounts not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of gamified versus nongamified health promotion interventions, including supervised exercise training (walking), on cardiometabolic health and fitness parameters in healthcare worker women.
results_summary: The gamified intervention was more effective than the nongamified one, improving body mass, waist circumference, HbA1C, triglycerides, blood pressure, and physical fitness (sit and reach, six-minute walking performance).
population_specificity: Women employees at a public outpatient health center in Brazil (n = 28 analyzed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (supervised exercise training included, but exact walking dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether pain affects motor learning, given overlapping brain regions involved in both processes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding Walking's effects, only noting the potential interaction between pain and motor learning.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) on improving walking ability in stroke patients and determine the optimal dosage of task-specific training based on RAGT.
results_summary: The study found that RAGT significantly improved lower limb function, gait speed, and activities of daily living (ADL) in stroke patients, with optimal effects seen at 30-60 minutes per day over 4 weeks. Subgroup analyses showed greater benefits for early-stage stroke patients and non-ambulatory individuals.
population_specificity: Stroke patients, particularly those in the early stage post-stroke or non-ambulatory.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 2-week step-reduction period followed by 4-week exercise rehabilitation on physical function, body composition, and metabolic health in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that short-term step-reduction did not significantly impact leg lean mass, physical function, or body composition in healthy older adults, though HDL cholesterol levels decreased slightly. Exercise rehabilitation after step-reduction also did not produce significant changes in the measured outcomes.
population_specificity: 70-80-year-olds asymptomatic for injury/illness (79% female).
effective_dosage: Step-reduction to <2000 daily steps (Period I), followed by exercise rehabilitation 4 times per week (Period II).
study_duration: 6 weeks total (2 weeks step-reduction, 4 weeks exercise rehabilitation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how walking in different environments (outdoors vs. indoors) affects psychophysiological responses to stress in individuals with coronary artery disease (CAD) during rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines plans to measure hemodynamic parameters, stress levels, and mood changes in CAD patients after walking in different environments, but specific results are not yet available as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Individuals with coronary artery disease (CAD) attending a cardiac rehabilitation program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS), alone or combined with other therapies, improves gait and balance in individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found moderate overall effects of tDCS on gait and balance in PD patients, with significant improvements in cadence, stride time, and timed up-and-go test performance. Some outcomes showed mixed results, but tDCS, especially when combined with other therapies, demonstrated notable benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of lower limb muscle strengthening on interface pressure, static stiffness index, dynamic stiffness index, and walking pressure amplitude in older adults undergoing inelastic compression therapy.
results_summary: The resistance training group showed increased lower limb muscle strength, which was accompanied by increased interface pressure during foot dorsiflexion and plantar flexion maneuvers, both while standing and during gait.
population_specificity: Forty-three healthy older adults of both sexes (Age: 66.2 ± 4.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an interdisciplinary weight loss and lifestyle intervention, including walking, on cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and self-reported physical fitness in adults with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in CRF (6% reduction in 2-km walking test time) and self-reported physical fitness (18% increase in IFIS score) at the intervention endpoint, with sustained benefits (10% and 22% improvements, respectively) at 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Men aged 18-65 years with moderate-to-severe OSA and a body mass index ≥25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a school-based walking intervention in increasing physical activity levels among adolescent girls (aged 12-14 years).
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly increase total physical activity compared to the control group, with no statistical difference observed post-intervention. Despite the feasibility study's promise, the scaled-up trial showed no measurable impact on device-measured physical activity.
population_specificity: Adolescent girls (aged 12-14 years) from schools in the border region of Ireland and Northern Ireland.
effective_dosage: 10-15 minute walks before school, at break, and lunch recess, encouraged to participate as often as possible each week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prehabilitation with exercise training (including walking) is feasible and safe for patients awaiting liver transplantation and if it improves clinical outcomes before or after transplantation.
results_summary: Prehabilitation with exercise training was found to be feasible and safe, with improvements noted in peak oxygen consumption, workload, 6-minute walking distance, and muscle strength. One study suggested a reduction in post-transplant hospital length of stay.
population_specificity: Adult liver transplant candidates, including those with cirrhosis or on the transplant list.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate prognostic models for predicting the recovery of independent walking in stroke patients during the subacute and chronic phases.
results_summary: The systematic review identified 30 prognostic models, with six showing excellent performance (AUC/accuracy ≥0.90), including one model with 100% accuracy in the subacute phase. However, external validation and clinical applicability of these models remain limited.
population_specificity: Stroke patients recovering in subacute and chronic phases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation, transcranial direct current stimulation, and cranial nerve noninvasive neuromodulation on functional balance, gait speed, and walking cadence in stroke patients.
results_summary: Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation combined with rehabilitation therapy significantly improved gait speed, walking cadence, and balance function compared to sham treatments. Transcranial direct current stimulation showed short-term benefits on the Time Up and Go test, but cranial nerve noninvasive neuromodulation lacked sufficient data for analysis.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week timing and coordination physical therapy intervention could reduce prefrontal cortex (PFC) activation during walking and improve gait performance in older adults at risk for mobility disability.
results_summary: The study found that PFC activation during walking generally did not improve post-intervention, and there were no significant differences between intervention and control arms. However, gait speed, particularly during dual-task conditions, and correct letter generation improved post-intervention, though these improvements did not differ by arm.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥65 at risk for mobility disability (n=42).
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week timing and coordination physical therapy intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term safety, tolerability, and efficacy of ambrisentan in pediatric patients (aged 8-<18 years) with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: The study found that ambrisentan, alone or combined with other PAH therapies, was well tolerated with clinical improvements, including a 17% mean improvement in 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) and stable or improved WHO functional class in all assessed participants. However, 55% experienced serious adverse events, though none were considered ambrisentan-related.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (aged 8-<18 years) with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
interactions: Most participants received concomitant phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (66%).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to categorize and diagnose parasomnias, including abnormal movements or behaviors during sleep, based on the ICSD-3-TR framework.
results_summary: The study summarized the diagnostic framework for parasomnias as outlined in the ICSD-3-TR, but did not report specific findings related to Walking.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of parasomnias).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes of arthroscopic lateral ankle ligament repair between skeletally immature and mature patients, focusing on walking, jogging, and return to sports.
results_summary: No significant differences were observed in walking and jogging outcomes between skeletally immature and mature patients post-surgery, but skeletally immature patients returned to full athletic activities significantly earlier.
population_specificity: Skeletally immature patients (epiphyseal line of distal fibula open) and skeletally mature adults with chronic lateral ankle instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of conventional rehabilitation (CR) alone versus CR combined with bodyweight-supported treadmill training (BWSTT) on walking speed, endurance, balance, mobility, and quality of life in stroke survivors.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in all measured outcomes, but the BWSTT group demonstrated particularly notable enhancements in comfortable walking speed (10MWT) and mobility (TUG test) compared to the CR-only group. The study concluded that combining BWSTT with CR offers additional benefits for functional mobility, though it is costlier than CR alone.
population_specificity: 30 stroke survivors (14 in CR-only group, 16 in CR+BWSTT group).
effective_dosage: CR: 30 minutes/day, 5 days/week; BWSTT: additional 30 minutes/session, 5 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the optimal dose and modality of exercise, including walking, for treating major depressive disorder compared to other treatments.
results_summary: Walking or jogging showed moderate reductions in depression (Hedges' g -0.62) compared to active controls, with effects proportional to intensity. Confidence in the results was low due to risk of bias in studies.
population_specificity: Participants meeting clinical cut-offs for major depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of mobile health (mhealth) technologies in improving walking distance for people with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: The study found no clear evidence that mhealth interventions improved absolute walking distance compared to usual care, with low-certainty evidence. Larger, well-designed RCTs are needed for reliable evaluation.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and a clinical diagnosis of intermittent claudication (IC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lower muscle strength and power in middle-aged breast cancer survivors (BCS) are associated with slower walking speed (WS) and whether resistance training (RT) improves WS by increasing strength and power.
results_summary: The study found that BCS had significantly lower muscle strength, power, and walking speed compared to women never diagnosed with cancer. Resistance training improved strength, power, and walking speed in BCS, with changes in WS positively associated with gains in strength and power.
population_specificity: Middle-aged women who are breast cancer survivors (BCS) and women of similar age never diagnosed with cancer (WNC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether manipulating peak vertical ground reaction force (vGRF) during walking influences changes in serum cartilage oligomeric matrix protein (sCOMP) concentrations in individuals who had undergone anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR).
results_summary: The study found no sCOMP differences across the entire cohort, but in a subgroup of sCOMP Increasers, manipulating peak loading during gait resulted in lower sCOMP concentrations, suggesting improved biochemical changes linked to cartilage health.
population_specificity: 40 ACLR individuals (48% female, age = 21.0 ± 4.4 years, BMI = 24.6 ± 3.1).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (biofeedback conditions: habitual, high loading, low loading, symmetrical loading).
study_duration: Four sessions, each involving walking on a treadmill for 3000 steps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gamification strategy informed by behavioral economics to increase daily physical activity in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that the gamification intervention increased daily step counts and improved PAD-specific quality of life, with follow-up suggesting durability of behavior change. The primary endpoint was change in daily steps over 16 weeks, with secondary endpoints including post-intervention step counts and patient-reported outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) seen in cardiology and vascular surgery clinics affiliated with the University of Pennsylvania Health System.
effective_dosage: Participants set a goal to increase daily step count by 33%-50% from baseline.
study_duration: 16 weeks of intervention, with an additional 8 weeks of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a hippotherapy simulator on balance, postural control, mobility, functional capacity, and independence level in people with stroke.
results_summary: The study found that the hippotherapy simulator improved balance and functional capacity in people with stroke when added to conventional exercises.
population_specificity: 26 people with stroke aged 18-65.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a telehealth-delivered clinician-supported exercise and weight loss program (Better Hip) is more effective than information-only control in improving hip pain on walking and physical function in people with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study compared a telehealth-supported program (Better Hip) with an information-only control group. Results will determine if the program improves walking-related hip pain and physical function at 6 months, but specific outcomes are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults aged 45+ with painful hip osteoarthritis, recruited from a health insurance fund.
effective_dosage: Six videoconferencing physiotherapist consultations, individualized home-based strengthening and physical activity programs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the reliability and agreement of step count measurements between a Fitbit Charge 4© and an ActiGraph wGT3X-BT in both controlled (treadmill) and free-living environments.
results_summary: The Fitbit showed good reliability for step count on a treadmill but overestimated daily steps in free-living conditions compared to the ActiGraph, with a mean absolute percentage error of 26.02%. Proportional bias was also observed, indicating the overestimation increased with higher step counts.
population_specificity: 30 adults aged 20-65 years (19 females).
study_duration: Seven days of free-living monitoring, plus two one-minute treadmill walking bouts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate caffeine's effects on balance, mobility, and health-related quality of life in persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: Daily caffeine consumption significantly improved objective measures of balance (BBS) and functional mobility (TUG), as well as subjective quality of life (MSIS-29), but did not significantly affect self-reported ambulatory disability (MSWS-12) or treatment efficacy (PGIC). Sex and age influenced some outcomes over time.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS; age 38.89 ± 9.85, 76.7% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of incorporating mHealth technology into a structured home-based walking intervention for individuals with recent myocardial infarction to improve cardiac rehabilitation uptake and long-term physical activity.
results_summary: The study is a feasibility trial assessing patient recruitment, retention, and outcome completion rates for a future definitive trial, but specific efficacy results regarding walking are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Individuals with recent myocardial infarction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of augmented reality treadmill-based gait adaptation training versus regular treadmill programs on mobility outcomes in stroke survivors.
results_summary: Both interventions improved mobility outcomes, but the augmented reality treadmill group showed greater improvements in obstacle avoidance, balance, turning, and stand-to-sit, along with a statistically significant reduction in fall rates during follow-up.
population_specificity: Forty stroke survivors (mean age ~50 years, onset of stroke ~110 days prior).
effective_dosage: Three training sessions per week for 5 weeks (15 sessions total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of interventions for Morton's neuroma (MN), a condition affecting walking due to foot pain.
results_summary: The study found low-certainty evidence that corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections (CS+LA) may result in little to no difference in pain or function for MN, and moderate-certainty evidence that ultrasound-guided CS+LA probably reduces pain and improves function.
population_specificity: 373 participants with Morton's neuroma confirmed by symptoms, clinical tests, and imaging (ultrasound or MRI).
study_duration: Post-intervention outcomes were assessed at 3-6 months for nonsurgical treatments and 12+ months for surgical outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of resistance exercise (RE) on sarcopenia and nutritional indicators in maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) patients, including its impact on muscle function, strength, and walking ability.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that RE significantly improved grip strength levels (MD = 4.39, 95% CI [3.14-5.64]) and had a positive effect on muscle function and strength in MHD patients, though walking ability was not explicitly quantified.
population_specificity: Maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a structured home-based exercise program (TiTo-SHB) with traditional walking advice in improving exercise capacity and health-related quality of life in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The TiTo-SHB group showed significant improvements in 6-minute walking distance, pain-free walking distance, ankle-brachial index, sit-to-stand test performance, and quality of life compared to the traditional walking advice group. All secondary outcomes also favored the TiTo-SHB intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) at Leriche-Fontaine's stage II (n=68, males=50, aged 73±9).
effective_dosage: TiTo-SHB group: two daily 8-minute sessions of pain-free interval walking; C-WA group: 30 minutes of walking at least three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of an autonomous neurorehabilitation system (InTandem) for improving walking in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study was a multi-site, prospective, interventional, randomized controlled trial, suggesting rigorous evaluation of the intervention's effects on walking post-stroke.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with reduced walking speed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of digital healthcare (DH) systems, including VR and AR, on pain and physical function in patients with knee joint pain.
results_summary: The study found that DH intervention significantly improved balance and pain levels, particularly in OA patients, but had no significant effect on knee joint range of motion or walking velocity.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with knee joint pain (194 males and 279 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of virtual reality-based therapy (VRBT) on functional capacity, pulmonary function, and functional mobility in patients with COPD.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that VRBT significantly improved functional capacity (6 Min Walking Test), pulmonary function (FEV1), and functional mobility (Get Up and Go Test) in COPD patients. The effects were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), mean age 65.7 ± 5.3 years.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness and comfort of Qing Dai cream walking jar as a nursing intervention for patients with psoriasis vulgaris.
results_summary: The Qing Dai cream walking jar significantly improved clinical symptoms, reduced itching and lesion severity, and enhanced quality of life and satisfaction compared to conventional care. The observation group showed higher effectiveness rates (94.74%) and better outcomes in PASI, DLQI, and satisfaction scores.
population_specificity: 76 patients with psoriasis vulgaris admitted to a hospital from February 2020 to February 2021.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify biological pathways connecting molecular aspects of Multiple Sclerosis (MS) with clinical phenotypes, including walking speed.
results_summary: The study identified a path linking protein MK03, immune cells, retinal nerve fiber layer thickness, and walking speed, connecting molecular mechanisms with higher-scale clinical outcomes in MS.
population_specificity: 328 patients with MS and 90 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of nutritional supplements in improving nutritional status, pulmonary function, physical performance, and quality of life in patients with stable COPD.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Walking; it focuses on nutritional supplements and their effects on COPD patients.
population_specificity: Patients affected by stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
study_duration: At least 2 weeks (intervention duration for nutritional support).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute, subacute, and late effects of postprandial walking on blood glucose levels in adults with type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: Walking reduced postprandial glucose excursion compared to rest, with a consistent blood glucose decline (-45 ± 24 mg/dL). However, hyperglycemia occurred in more than half of participants after exercise, necessitating insulin correction, and nocturnal hypoglycemia was more frequent post-exercise.
population_specificity: Adults with type 1 diabetes (n = 8, aged 44 ± 13 years, BMI 24 ± 2.1).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of walking performed 60 minutes after a standardized meal.
study_duration: Acute effects during exercise, subacute (≤2 h after), and late effects (≤24 h after).
interactions: Prandial insulin reductions were noted as necessary precautions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the pattern and predictors of heterogeneity in change for moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) among persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) following a behavioral intervention.
results_summary: The study found significant heterogeneity in MVPA change, with baseline MVPA, walking impairment, and race predicting 25.6% of the variance in MVPA change for the behavioral intervention group. The intervention showed greater heterogeneity in MVPA change compared to the control condition.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) (N = 318).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a supervised multicomponent exercise program, including walking, could reduce hospital-associated disability (HAD) incidence in hospitalized older adults at discharge and 3 months post-discharge.
results_summary: The intervention showed no significant reduction in HAD incidence when measured by the Katz Index but demonstrated benefits in secondary outcomes, including reduced HAD incidence (Barthel Index), lesser decline in ambulatory capacity, and improved physical performance at discharge. No significant effects were observed for readmissions, falls, or mortality.
population_specificity: Hospitalized adults aged 75 years or older in an acute care for elders unit at a tertiary public hospital in Madrid, Spain.
effective_dosage: Daily strength, balance, and walking exercises along with inspiratory muscle training during hospitalization, plus health education and telephone counseling post-discharge.
study_duration: During hospitalization (median length of stay: 7 days) and follow-up at 3 months post-discharge.

study_goal: To determine the effect of a school traffic warden program on increasing driver yield and safe child pedestrian crossing behavior in Kampala, Uganda.
results_summary: The school traffic warden program significantly increased driver yield (aPR 7.2) and improved safe child crossing behavior (aPR 1.7), including walking while crossing (aPR 1.2). The intervention was associated with safer pedestrian practices such as stopping at the curb and avoiding illegal crossings.
population_specificity: Primary school children in Kampala, Uganda.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention involved trained adult traffic wardens).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate patients' perceptions of the effectiveness and tolerability of nabiximols oromucosal spray (Sativex) in people with multiple sclerosis (MS) spasticity.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of Walking.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (MS) spasticity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether using a mobile patient lift could facilitate earlier mobilization (including sitting, standing, transfers, and walking) in ventilated ICU patients.
results_summary: The intervention group stood faster (1.0 vs. 3.0 days) and had higher Functional Status Score-ICU scores at discharge, but no differences were observed in Medical Research Council scores, Barthel index, ICU stay length, or ventilator-free days.
population_specificity: Ventilated ICU patients expected to require ventilation for at least 48 hours in an academic ICU in Tokyo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a telerehabilitation exercise program (including walking) versus a "wait-and-see" approach on physical exertion, quality of life, dyspnea severity, and physiological outcomes in post-COVID patients with fatigue and dyspnea.
results_summary: The telerehabilitation group showed significant improvements in physical exertion, dyspnea severity, quality of life, and 6-minute walking test performance compared to the control group. Physiological benefits included lower exertion scores, improved oxygen saturation at rest, and reduced heart rate after exertion.
population_specificity: Patients with post-COVID fatigue and dyspnea (n=64).
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included patient education, physical activity, airway clearing, and breathing exercises).
study_duration: Assessed at baseline, post-program, and at 1- and 3-month follow-ups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the rehabilitative effects of electrical stimulation therapy on gait performance in stroke patients.
results_summary: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) showed positive effects on postural stability and gait velocity in stroke patients, but no significant differences were observed in the 10-meter walk test or 6-minute walk test compared to controls. The evidence for overall efficacy was limited, with high heterogeneity in some outcomes.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of oral therapies targeting the prostacyclin pathway in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) who had an unsatisfactory response to first-line therapy.
results_summary: Oral treprostinil and beraprost significantly increased 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), while selexipag showed a non-significant increase. Selexipag and oral treprostinil significantly reduced clinical worsening compared to placebo, whereas beraprost did not. No significant differences in efficacy or safety were found between oral treprostinil and selexipag.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and an unsatisfactory response to first-line therapy (n=3023).

study_goal: To explore the effect of acupuncture combined with lower limb gait rehabilitation robot training on walking function in stroke patients with hemiplegia.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvement in walking function parameters, but the intervention group (receiving robot-assisted training) demonstrated significantly better outcomes in functional ambulation, gait scale scores, and spatiotemporal walking parameters.
population_specificity: Fifty-six patients with hemiplegia after stroke.
effective_dosage: 5 sessions per week (specific duration per session not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of three different intensities of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) on functional outcomes in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: High-intensity and comfortable-intensity RAGT improved gross motor function, while comfortable-intensity training also enhanced gait speed. Low-intensity training improved stability, and all groups showed functional performance gains, with the greatest improvement in the comfortable-intensity group.
population_specificity: Thirty children (ages 4-10, GMFCS levels II-III) with cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week for 6 weeks, varying intensities (high, low, comfortable).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether mobile physical activity coaching (promoting walking) could increase daily step counts and improve cardiometabolic health.
results_summary: The mobile coaching intervention did not significantly affect step count (β -124.0, 95% CI -723.1 to 475.1) or any cardiometabolic risk markers.
population_specificity: Regular supermarket shoppers aged 30-80 years in socially disadvantaged neighborhoods in the Netherlands (73% female, average age 58).
effective_dosage: Not specified (step counter and mobile coaching app usage).
study_duration: 12 months (with measurements at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review walking tests and their measurement properties in adults with inherited or genetic neuromuscular diseases (NMDs) to help clinicians and researchers choose appropriate tests.
results_summary: The review found that most walking outcomes were valid and reliable in NMDs, with the 6MWT being the most studied test. However, studies on responsiveness and minimal important differences were lacking or inadequate.
population_specificity: Adults with inherited or genetic neuromuscular diseases (NMDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report the clinical and genetic characteristics of a patient with frontotemporal dementia (FTD) exhibiting abnormal behavior and unstable walking.
results_summary: The study identified a patient with FTD who exhibited unstable walking and frequent falls, along with other behavioral and cognitive symptoms. Genetic analysis revealed mutations in the GRN and ErbB4 genes, suggesting their potential role in FTD pathogenesis.
population_specificity: A 52-year-old man with frontotemporal dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether machine learning approaches could predict the response to pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) in individuals recovering from a COPD exacerbation, focusing on changes in walking distance and other clinical measures.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with lower baseline walking distance (6MWT) and less severe airway obstruction showed greater improvements in walking distance, while older and more dyspnoeic individuals had lower improvements. Predictive models had varying accuracy, with mean absolute errors ranging from 0.32 to 44.70 for different outcome measures.
population_specificity: Individuals recovering from a COPD exacerbation (ECOPD).

study_goal: To explore the clinical efficacy and potential mechanisms of waist and knee scraping therapy for treating knee osteoarthritis (KOA) through clinical and animal studies.
results_summary: Waist and knee scraping therapy significantly improved clinical efficacy, reduced pain and stiffness, and enhanced joint function in KOA patients, with more pronounced effects than knee scraping alone. In animal studies, scraping therapy reduced inflammatory markers and improved pain thresholds, particularly in the waist and knee scraping group.
population_specificity: 90 KOA patients and KOA rat models.
study_duration: 60 days for clinical study; 4 weeks for animal study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of walking in managing peripheral artery disease, focusing on its impact on walking distance and limb preservation.
results_summary: The study highlights that supervised exercise therapy, including walking, is a key component in managing peripheral artery disease, improving walking distance and reducing the risk of limb loss. It also emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and lifestyle modification alongside medical care.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease caused by atherosclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if independent walking at 3 and 6 months poststroke could be accurately predicted within the first 72 hours using simple clinical bedside tests.
results_summary: The study developed two predictive equations for walking ability at 3 and 6 months poststroke, showing high sensitivity and positive predictive value at 3 months, and moderate sensitivity with high specificity and positive predictive value at 6 months. The findings suggest these equations can help identify individuals at high risk of walking dependence early after stroke.
population_specificity: Adults with first-ever stroke evaluated at 3 (N=263) and 6 (N=212) months poststroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the rate of step count measurement (pedometer use) influenced glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Patients with a reduced step count measurement rate experienced worsened glycemic control, with a significant between-group difference in HbA1c change (0.516%, p=0.012). The study concluded that consistent step count measurement may improve glycemic outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes from eight hospitals in Japan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (step count monitoring via pedometer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a home-based exercise program (TeGeCoach) on self-reported walking ability in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: The TeGeCoach program significantly improved Walking Impairment Questionnaire (WIQ) scores at 12 and 24 months compared to routine care, with small effect sizes. Some secondary outcomes, like physical health-related quality of life and patient activation, also showed positive results.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic intermittent claudication insured by German statutory health insurance funds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the differential diagnosis of foot drop, focusing on clinical presentation, recovery, and surgical treatment options.
results_summary: The study found that foot drop can result from various nerve injuries beyond the common peroneal nerve, each with distinct clinical presentations and recovery prospects. Surgical techniques for treatment remain inconsistent, but fascicular nerve transfer shows promise for future innovation.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from foot drop in the United States (at least 128,000 annually).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence of sarcopenia and its correlation with functional capacity in older patients undergoing inpatient cardiac rehabilitation (iCR) after cardiac procedures.
results_summary: The study found a high prevalence of sarcopenia (35%) at baseline, which decreased to 23% at follow-up. Sarcopenic patients showed significant improvements in functional capacity (measured by SARC-F) and had poor baseline functional performance, indicating potential benefits from prehabilitation.
population_specificity: Older patients (≥75 years) undergoing inpatient cardiac rehabilitation after cardiac procedures in Germany.
study_duration: Baseline assessment during iCR and follow-up 3 months later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability and effectiveness of a home-based walking exercise intervention (MOSAIC) for adults with Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD).
results_summary: Participants found MOSAIC to be an effective, low-burden intervention that improved their confidence, walking capacity, and outlook on self-managing PAD. Physiotherapists were seen as supportive in helping participants understand and adhere to walking as a treatment.
population_specificity: Adults with Peripheral Arterial Disease (mean age 67, 70% male, 55% White British).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a physiotherapy-led group exercise program combined with self-management strategies could increase free-living physical activity (measured by daily step count) in people with mild-moderate Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study incorporated treadmill walking and other exercises targeting aerobic fitness, strength, balance, and gait performance, alongside self-management strategies. Outcomes were measured at baseline, post-intervention, and 6-month follow-up, with potential to improve free-living physical activity in PD patients.
population_specificity: People with mild-moderate Parkinson's disease (n=92).
effective_dosage: Twelve 80-minute sessions over 4 weeks, in groups of up to 4 participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of physical activity, including walking, in post-stroke recovery, particularly under COVID-19 pandemic conditions.
results_summary: The study found that physical activity and exercise, including walking, improved cardiovascular health, walking capacity, and upper limb strength in stroke survivors. However, pandemic-related barriers like fear of infection and repurposed rehabilitation units limited access to these interventions.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors, particularly those affected by COVID-19-related neurological complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a coaching intervention on physical activity and falls rate in community-dwelling older adults aged 60+ years.
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly affect physical activity counts per minute or falls rate but improved daily steps, MVPA, self-reported walking hours, well-being, quality of life, and disability. No significant differences were found in other secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 60+ years (mean age 74, 70% women).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included activity tracker and up to 19 telephone coaching sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how improvements in physical function (including walking) and dialysis-related symptoms from intradialytic exercise affect health-related quality of life (HRQOL) in haemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that improvements in Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) scores, self-perceived physical fitness, and extended walking distance significantly enhanced HRQOL in haemodialysis patients undergoing intradialytic exercise.
population_specificity: Haemodialysis patients participating in an intradialytic exercise program.
effective_dosage: Exercise program (stretching and resistance training) three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of physical activity, including walking, in managing symptomatic intracranial atherosclerotic stenosis (sICAS) and reducing stroke recurrence.
results_summary: The study found that physical activity, such as walking, is beneficial for patients with sICAS who are not severely disabled, recommending at least 10 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity 4 times a week. Walking was encouraged as part of a broader aggressive medical management strategy.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic intracranial atherosclerotic stenosis (sICAS) who are not severely disabled.
effective_dosage: Minimum of 10 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity 4 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if toddler's fractures could be safely and effectively treated with observation alone instead of casting.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in ambulation time between casted and non-casted groups, with all fractures healing uneventfully and no cast complications reported. Both treatment methods appeared safe and effective, suggesting immobilization may not be necessary.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (toddlers) with toddler's fractures.
study_duration: 21-day observation period with follow-ups at 3 and 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify which submaximal field walking tests are used in cardiopulmonary assessment of children and adolescents with congenital heart disease (CHD) and assess their adherence to standardization protocols.
results_summary: The six-minute walk test was the only submaximal field test identified, but its application lacked standardization, complicating result comparisons. Only one study showed good methodological quality, while others had low to moderate risk of bias.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (5-18 years) with congenital heart disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effects of rhythmic auditory stimulation (RAS) on functional ambulation and walking assistive device use in stroke patients, and to compare the effects of RAS and music-based RAS based on the lesioned area.
results_summary: RAS improved walking and balance parameters in stroke patients across all phases compared to baseline and conventional treatment groups, though functional ambulation and assistive device use were inconsistently reported. RAS may be as effective as other complementary therapies like horse-riding and visual cueing.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors (948 participants across 21 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Tai Chi and brisk walking on non-motor symptoms in early-stage Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: Brisk walking showed some improvement in non-motor symptoms, but Tai Chi had greater advantages in improving cognition and sleep. The study did not highlight significant adverse effects for brisk walking.
population_specificity: Early-stage Parkinson's disease patients (N=31 in brisk walking group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency/duration implied by intervention length).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare ambulatory outcomes in children with ONTD repaired prenatally (via fetoscopic or open hysterotomy) versus postnatally and identify predictors of independent walking at 30 months.
results_summary: Prenatal repair resulted in a higher proportion of children walking independently (51.8%) compared to postnatal repair (15.7%), with no difference between fetoscopic and open methods. Predictors of walking included intact motor function at birth/12 months, lesion level below L2, and female gender.
population_specificity: Children with open neural tube defects (ONTD) repaired prenatally (n=110) or postnatally (n=51) at a single tertiary hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether idiopathic toe walking (ITW) is associated with impaired health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and if the severity of equinus contracture correlates with the degree of impairment.
results_summary: The study found that ITW in children is associated with significant reductions in physical, school and play, and emotional HRQoL domains compared to healthy controls. A moderate correlation was observed between the severity of equinus contracture and worse physical domain scores.
population_specificity: Children younger than 18 years with idiopathic toe walking (ITW) from 12 pediatric orthopaedic centers in the UK.
study_duration: Data collected between May 2022 and July 2022 (cross-sectional study, no intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of TENS, CRF, and PRF treatments in patients with lumbar facet syndrome (LFS), including assessing improvements in pain, mobility, and quality of life.
results_summary: All three treatments (CRF, TENS, PRF) showed statistically significant improvements in pain scores, mobility (20-meter walking times, 6-min walking distances), disability, and quality of life at 1 and 6 months, with no significant differences between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar facet syndrome (LFS) refractory to medical treatment for at least 3 months.
effective_dosage: TENS was administered for 30 minutes a day for 15 days; CRF and PRF dosages were not specified.
study_duration: Assessments were conducted at baseline, 1 month, and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of three equine therapy approaches on gross motor function in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that equine-assisted therapy (EAT) significantly improved gross motor function in children with cerebral palsy, with Horseback Riding Simulator (HRS) being the second most effective and cost-effective option. Therapeutic Horseback Riding (THR) also showed some rehabilitative value.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy, average age 8.03 years.
effective_dosage: Session durations of 30 to 45 minutes, 2 to 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if postmeal walking (PMW) is an effective and feasible alternative to standard continuous walking for managing gestational diabetes (GDM).
results_summary: Postmeal walking did not improve postprandial glucose outcomes compared to standard care, with higher postprandial glucose at dinner in the PMW group. Both groups showed high adherence to prescribed physical activity, but PMW led to more sedentary time and less stepping time.
population_specificity: Forty women with gestational diabetes (GDM) between 28 and 30 weeks of gestation.
effective_dosage: Standard care (30-min continuous walking most days per week) or PMW (daily 10-min walks after three main meals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the prevention and treatment effects of different exercise methods, including walking, on perinatal depression.
results_summary: The study found that walking (specifically stroller walking) had a moderate equivalent stress intervention effect on treating postpartum depression, ranking lower than aerobic exercise, water exercise, yoga, and fertility dance.
population_specificity: Pregnant and postpartum women (total of 5282 participants).
