study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of high-intensity low-volume (HIFT) versus low-intensity high-volume (LIFT) functional training in elderly type-2 diabetes (T2D) patients with cognitive impairment.
results_summary: HIFT showed higher adherence, safety, and acceptability than LIFT, with significant improvements in cognitive function (MMSE, Stroop), physical fitness (6MWT), and metabolic markers (FBG, insulin, HbA1c). HIFT also outperformed LIFT in processing speed, memory, balance, and strength tests.
population_specificity: Elderly T2D patients (67.5 ± 5.8 years) with cognitive impairment (MMSE ≤ 23).
effective_dosage: HIFT: 3 sessions/week at 120-125% lactate threshold; LIFT: 5 sessions/week at 70-75% lactate threshold.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether volunteer-assisted walking improves physical performance and health in older people with restricted mobility.
results_summary: The study did not show superiority of the walking intervention in improving physical function or other health outcomes in intention-to-treat analyses, but exploratory analyses suggested benefits for those who walked regularly. The intervention appeared safe regarding falls.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65+ with restricted mobility due to physical limitations, recruited from nursing homes and community settings (79% female).
effective_dosage: 30-50 min walks up to three times a week.

study_goal: The abstract does not focus on studying Walking but rather discusses onychomycosis and its treatment.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Walking.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract discusses onychomycosis patients generally).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of high versus standard enteral protein provision on functional recovery, including walking ability (measured by the 6-min walking test), in critically ill, mechanically ventilated patients.
results_summary: The study assessed walking ability via the 6-min walking test as a secondary outcome, but specific results regarding its efficacy were not detailed in the abstract. The analysis plan emphasized clinically important effect sizes and probabilistic interpretation under a Bayesian framework.
population_specificity: Adult, mechanically ventilated critically ill patients, including subgroups with acute kidney injury, severe multi-organ failure, and sepsis.
study_duration: Follow-up period included assessments at 30, 90, and 180 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a core outcome measurement set (COS-GT) for gluteal tendinopathy (GT) to guide clinical practice and future research trials.
results_summary: The study identified interim measures for GT, including pain at night, pain with stair walking, and hip abduction strength, but found no measures with adequate clinimetric properties for a definitive COS-GT. Expert health professionals recommended additional measures like pain over the last week and specific quality-of-life assessments for clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients with gluteal tendinopathy and expert health professionals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Tadalafil on pulmonary function and quality of life in patients with severe asthma, including its effect on 6-minute walking distance.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvement in pulmonary function, quality of life, or 6-minute walking distance in the Tadalafil group compared to the placebo group after one month of treatment.
population_specificity: 44 patients with severe asthma

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of using allied health assistants to provide daily inpatient mobility rehabilitation (including walking) for patients with multimorbidity in acute hospital settings.
results_summary: The study assessed feasibility through patient satisfaction, participation rates, implementation metrics, and cost, but specific results on walking outcomes were not detailed in the abstract. Secondary outcomes included physical activity (daily walking time), functional activity, and hospital-related metrics.
population_specificity: Adult inpatients in an acute hospital with a diagnosis of multimorbidity who could walk independently before admission.
effective_dosage: Daily mobilisation (frequency specified, exact duration per session not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of hospital stay (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review non-pharmacological treatment approaches for improving gait and balance in persons with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The study found that non-pharmacological interventions, including exercise, physiotherapy, and electrical stimulation, improved quality of life, reduced disability, fatigue, and muscle spasticity in PwMS, though long-term effects of some methods require further research.
population_specificity: Persons with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update evidence-based recommendations for the non-pharmacological management of hip and knee osteoarthritis, including the role of walking and other interventions.
results_summary: The study found that walking, as part of an individualized, multicomponent management plan, is effective for improving function and quality of life in hip and knee OA patients. Recommendations emphasized tailoring exercise dosage and progression, as well as using assistive devices like walking aids.
population_specificity: Individuals with hip and knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a 3-month exercise program (including walking) based on patient-preferred delivery modes (home-based, personal training, or group-based) in patients with metastatic cancer.
results_summary: The study found that the exercise program was feasible, with high attendance (92%) and adherence (88%), and improved cardiorespiratory fitness, flexibility, and several quality-of-life domains, though no changes were observed in muscle strength or anthropometric values.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic cancer (n=44).
effective_dosage: Aerobic and resistance activities performed twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of VR combined with pulmonary rehabilitation for improving lung function and related outcomes in patients with COPD.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that VR combined with pulmonary rehabilitation significantly improved lung function (FEV1%, FEV1/FVC), dyspnea, 6-minute walking test performance, and mood (depression and anxiety) compared to pulmonary rehabilitation alone.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the expectations, usability, and clinical efficacy of therapeutic footwear in individuals with diabetes at moderate to high risk of foot ulceration.
results_summary: Therapeutic footwear exceeded patients' anticipated use in 94% of cases, improved walking ability perception, and reduced ulceration rates.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes at moderate to high risk of foot ulceration receiving their first therapeutic footwear prescription.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-intensity training (HIT) focused on stepping practice versus conventional training on walking and secondary outcomes in individuals with chronic traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: HIT led to greater improvements in walking distance (6-min walk test), peak treadmill speed, aerobic capacity, efficiency, and selected cognitive assessments compared to conventional training. Moderate associations were found between stepping practice and outcomes.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with chronic TBI (>6 months post-injury).
effective_dosage: Up to 15 sessions over five weeks (HIT or conventional training).
study_duration: Five weeks per intervention phase, with a >4-week crossover period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the sensorimotor mechanism of smart prostheses in individuals with ankle amputations during walking.
results_summary: The review found that pressure sensors and neural stimulation via encoded algorithms can provide continuous tactile and positional feedback of the artificial leg during walking, leading to functional and cognitive benefits. However, movement strategies for smart prostheses remain understudied.
population_specificity: Individuals with ankle joint amputations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the immediate effects of different mask types (control, N95, surgical) on cardiopulmonary function, subjective perceptions, and 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) in COPD patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results, as the study appears to be in progress or not yet concluded. Outcomes will include 6MWD, blood oxygen saturation, blood pressure, pulse rate, Borg score, RPE score, and subjective perception scores.
population_specificity: Stable COPD patients (n=129)
study_duration: Immediate effects assessed during 6-minute walk and seated tests

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of exercise and motor interventions, including gait training, on physical activity and motor outcomes in adults with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that gait training improved gait velocity, quality of gait, and ankle stiffness more effectively than standard care or neurodevelopmental treatment, while balance training enhanced walking self-confidence and perceived balance change. However, whole-body vibration and resistance training showed no significant advantages over typical exercise programs for strength or gait function.
population_specificity: Adults with cerebral palsy (439 participants across 25 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and effects of a sleep intervention program incorporating walking as part of a broader strategy to improve sleep in persons living with dementia and their care partners.
results_summary: The study found modest improvements in sleep efficiency and total wake time for both groups, with slightly better outcomes in the intervention group, though trends were nonsignificant. Walking was part of a multi-component intervention, making its isolated effects unclear.
population_specificity: Persons living with dementia and their family care partners.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking was part of a broader intervention).
study_duration: 5 sessions, with outcomes measured up to 3-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of Fu's subcutaneous needling (FSN) and electroacupuncture (EA) in improving pain symptoms, joint stability, and function in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both FSN and EA showed favorable results, but FSN demonstrated significantly greater improvements in claudication, joint stability, swelling, pain, and range of motion compared to EA. The benefits of FSN were maintained for at least 3 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: 62 patients with early or medial stage knee osteoarthritis (60 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and synthesize evidence on walking interventions and their impact on fear of falling (FOF) among community-dwelling older adults without cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The review found that multicomponent walking interventions were commonly used, with the Falls Efficacy Scale-International being the most frequent tool to assess FOF. Walking interventions showed potential in addressing FOF, though the abstract does not detail specific efficacy outcomes.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults without cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Taichi versus conventional exercise (CE) on functional mobility and balance in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Taichi showed greater improvements in functional mobility and balance compared to CE, particularly when compared to single-type CE. The study included 12 studies with 2,901 participants, indicating consistent benefits.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficacy of cycling using functional electrical stimulation therapy (FEST) to improve motor function and lower limb activity in post-stroke individuals.
results_summary: Moderate-quality evidence suggests that cycling using FEST combined with exercise programs improves trunk control and walking distance, while FEST alone showed similar benefits in strength, balance, walking speed, and activities of daily living compared to exercise programs.
population_specificity: Subacute post-stroke individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of textured versus smooth insoles on gait, foot sensation, and patient-reported outcomes in people with Multiple Sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found no differences in stride width between groups when walking over even or uneven surfaces, indicating that textured insoles did not significantly alter walking or foot sensation in people with MS who have limited foot sensory loss.
population_specificity: Thirty ambulant men and women with Multiple Sclerosis (Disease Steps rating 1-4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cervical mobilization on balance and gait parameters in post-stroke adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of cervical mobilization on walking, but the study design suggests an investigation into its potential benefits.
population_specificity: 24 adults aged 30-65 years with post-stroke deficits (MMSE ≥24, Modified Rankin scale ≤3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-frequency repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (LF-rTMS) on gait function recovery in stroke patients.
results_summary: LF-rTMS significantly improved gait parameters, joint motion angles, and neurophysiologic measures (MEP latency/CMCT) in stroke patients, with better efficacy than conventional treatment alone. MEP latency and CMCT changes were correlated with gait improvements, providing objective evidence for LF-rTMS's benefits.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with walking dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether downhill treadmill walking exercise (DTWE) could improve thoracic kyphosis and forward head posture (FHP) compared to standard treadmill walking exercise (STWE).
results_summary: The DTWE group showed significant improvements in craniovertebral angle and thoracic erector spinae muscle activity, along with reductions in thoracic kyphosis and cervical muscle activity, compared to the STWE group. No significant changes were observed in lumbar lordosis or pelvic tilt angles.
population_specificity: 28 male participants with thoracic kyphosis and forward head posture.
effective_dosage: 30-minute exercise sessions, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare care processes and 30-day outcomes, including mobility and rehabilitation, in hip fracture patients with different mental statuses at admission.
results_summary: Patients with poorer mental status (>2 SPMSQ score) had worse mobility (26.0% vs. 4.5% non-independent walking ability at admission, 44.4% vs. 24.9% at one month), lower rates of early mobilization, and higher mortality. They also received less anti-osteoporotic medication and were less likely to return home post-discharge.
population_specificity: Elderly hip fracture patients (aged 85.3–87.7 years) from 76 Spanish hospitals (2017–2019), stratified by mental status (SPMSQ score).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elevated IgG levels following IVIg administration are linked to improved recovery of independent walking at 6 months in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome.
results_summary: Patients with a low increase in IgG levels (< 1945.5 mg/dl) at 7 days post-treatment exhibited more severe clinical manifestations and poorer walking outcomes at 6 months. Higher IgG increases were associated with better walking recovery.
population_specificity: 42 patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome.
effective_dosage: Not specified (IgG levels measured, but exact IVIg dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a home-based multi-modal program of proprioceptive rehabilitation and strength training could improve balance performance in people with CMT Type 1A.
results_summary: The intervention was feasible and safe, with strong effect sizes in functional balance and walking measures, and moderate improvements in postural stability, though lower limb strength changes were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Fourteen participants with Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 1A.
effective_dosage: 12 weeks of balance training, supported by three home visits from a physiotherapist.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the influencing factors of falls among older adults in Chinese nursing homes.
results_summary: The study found that falls among older adults in Chinese nursing homes were common (32% incidence), with key influencing factors including age, gender, visual impairment, sedative-hypnotics, fear of falling, hypertension, and cognitive status.
population_specificity: Older adults in Chinese nursing homes (3503 participants across 11 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining lower-extremity muscle power training with regular cardiac rehabilitation improves muscle strength, balance function, and walking ability in older adults with heart failure.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly greater improvement in lower-extremity muscle power and larger effect sizes in balance and walking tests compared to the control group, suggesting enhanced dynamic balance and walking ability. Both groups improved, but the intervention group demonstrated more substantial gains.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 66–89 years) with non-severe heart failure (17 males, 14 females).
effective_dosage: Not specified (additional lower-extremity muscle power training alongside regular cardiac rehabilitation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether self-directed walking (measured via step counts) could reduce patient-reported toxicities and side effects during chemotherapy for early breast cancer.
results_summary: Higher step counts (≥30,000 steps/week) were associated with significantly lower risks of fatigue, anxiety, nausea, depression, multiple severe symptoms, and dose reductions during chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Women with early breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy (mean age 56, 76% White).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of bisoprolol in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including its effects on lung function, exercise performance (6-minute walking distance), and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: The study found that bisoprolol improved lung function (FEV1, FEV1%, FVC), increased 6-minute walking distance, and reduced inflammatory markers (IL-6, IL-8, CRP) in COPD patients, with no significant safety concerns.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including those with or without heart failure.

study_goal: To explore the efficacy of selective dorsal rhizotomy (SDR) followed by physical training on gross motor function, functional balance, walking capacity, selective motor control, and energy cost of walking in children with spastic diplegia.
results_summary: Both the control and SDR groups showed significant improvements in gross motor function, functional balance, walking capacity, selective motor control, and energy cost of walking from baseline to 6-month and 1-year follow-ups, with greater improvements in the SDR group.
population_specificity: 42 children with spastic diplegia aged 5 to 8 years.
effective_dosage: Physical training 3 times a week for 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single bout of light-intensity walking could improve sleep quality in bladder cancer patients with sleep disorders.
results_summary: The study found that light-intensity walking significantly reduced sleep latency in bladder cancer patients with sleep disorders, though no significant effects were observed for other sleep parameters.
population_specificity: 14 patients with bladder cancer and sleep disorders.
effective_dosage: Single bout of light-intensity walking (specific duration/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of external diaphragm pacing combined with conventional rehabilitation therapies (EDP-CRTs) on pulmonary function and exercise capacity in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The pooled results from 13 studies showed significant benefits of EDP-CRTs on pulmonary function, exercise capacity, and PaCO2 levels in COPD patients. The meta-analysis supports the effectiveness of this combined therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers investigated whether exogenous butyrate could improve sarcopenia and physical capacity in COPD patients by addressing intestinal permeability and neuromuscular junction integrity.
results_summary: Butyrate supplementation improved handgrip strength, gait speed, postural balance, and chair-rise ability while reducing markers of intestinal leak, systemic bacterial load, and NMJ degradation in COPD patients.
population_specificity: COPD patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-intensity walking intervention (FAST), a step activity monitoring behavioral intervention (SAM), or a combined intervention (FAST+SAM) on physical activity (steps/day) in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The study found that only the step activity monitoring behavioral intervention (SAM) significantly increased steps/day in individuals with chronic stroke, while the high-intensity walking intervention (FAST) and combined intervention (FAST+SAM) did not show significant improvements.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 21-85 years with chronic stroke (≥6 months post-stroke), able to walk without physical assistance.
effective_dosage: FAST: 2-3 sessions/week at 70-80% heart rate reserve; SAM: daily feedback and goal setting.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of physical recreation, including walking-related activities, on participation, mobility, and quality of life for adults with disabilities.
results_summary: Physical recreation improved mobility, walking endurance, balance, and quality of life (physical health) but did not significantly improve walking speed. The evidence certainty was low to very low.
population_specificity: Adults with physical or intellectual disabilities (mean age 55 years).
effective_dosage: Mean frequency and duration was 65 min/session, two times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify pain trajectory patterns in people with knee or hip osteoarthritis participating in a digital self-management program and examine associations between baseline characteristics and these trajectories.
results_summary: The study identified four distinct pain trajectory classes, with the majority showing improvement in pain levels, particularly within the first 20 weeks. Baseline factors like lower activity impairment, no walking difficulties, and higher physical activity were associated with better pain outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with knee or hip osteoarthritis (n=16,274) enrolled in a digital self-management program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Trimetazidine (TMZ) could improve cardiac function, reduce cardiac events, and enhance exercise performance and quality of life in adult patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease (CCHD).
results_summary: The study did not report results related to Walking, as it focused on TMZ's effects on cardiac function in CCHD patients.
population_specificity: Adult patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease (CCHD) who were not able to receive surgery.
effective_dosage: 20 mg TMZ 3 times a day (or placebo equivalent).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of robotic gait training versus conventional physiotherapy in improving walking ability after botulinum toxin type A (BTx-A) injections in stroke patients with lower limb spasticity.
results_summary: Robotic gait training significantly improved walking performance (measured by the 6-minute walk test) more than conventional physiotherapy after BTx-A injections, with a mean difference of 33 meters favoring the robotic group initially and a 30-meter difference persisting after both treatments. Both groups showed improvement, but robotic training yielded better outcomes.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients with triceps surae spasticity causing gait impairment (n=33).
effective_dosage: Not specified (BTx-A injection details not provided).
study_duration: 4 weeks total (2 weeks robotic gait training + 2 weeks conventional physiotherapy or vice versa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term functional and clinical effects of a 4-week barefoot versus shod treadmill walking program for individuals with persistent plantar heel pain (PPHP).
results_summary: Both walking programs improved pain, function, and quality of life, with the barefoot group showing greater improvements in physical function, role limitations, pain pressure thresholds, and pain tolerance. Both groups increased walking speed, time spent walking, and time outdoors.
population_specificity: 52 participants with persistent plantar heel pain (PPHP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effect size of an educational physical activity intervention using an ICT-based monitoring system for in-hospital patients undergoing cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: The ICT group showed significantly higher step counts (mean difference=1370 steps) and longer 6-minute walking distances (mean difference=81.6 m) compared to the control group, indicating improved physical activity and function during hospitalization.
population_specificity: In-hospital patients undergoing cardiac rehabilitation (median age 70 years; 24 men).
study_duration: Median duration of wearing the accelerometer was 4 days in the ICT group and 6 days in the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining epidural electrical stimulation (EES), mental imagery practice, and robotic neuro-rehabilitation could restore volitional motor control and independent overground walking in participants with chronic motor-complete thoracic spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Two participants regained volitional motor control below their injury level and achieved independent overground walking within a month of post-operative stimulation and rehabilitation, with no adverse events and improved truncal stability.
population_specificity: Chronic motor-complete thoracic SCI patients.
study_duration: One month post-operative stimulation and rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bilateral upper limb robot-assisted training (BRT) compared to conventional training (CT) on upper limb motor function and quality of life in stroke patients, using EEG to assess brain activity changes.
results_summary: BRT improved activities of daily living (ADL) more than CT, though both groups showed significant within-group improvements in upper limb motor function. BRT also enhanced functional brain connectivity and beta rhythm power spectrum energy compared to CT.
population_specificity: 24 stroke patients with hemiplegia.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of BRT or CT per day, 6 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if hip strategy-based motion control training improves walking function recovery in patients with ankle injuries compared to routine rehabilitation alone.
results_summary: The study found that both groups improved after treatment, but the observation group (receiving additional hip strategy-based training) showed significantly better outcomes in balance, gait, and functional tests compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 62 patients with ankle injuries (28-56 years old, predominantly male).
effective_dosage: Not specified (training included hip muscle strength, stability control, balance, and gait analysis for six weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, feasibility, and probable efficacy of intramuscular administration of allogeneic Wharton's jelly-derived mesenchymal stem cells (WJ-MSCs) in type 2 diabetes patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI).
results_summary: The study found no adverse events or amputations during the 6-month follow-up, with significant improvements in pain-free walking time, visual analogue scale (VAS) scores, and foot and ankle disability index (FADI) compared to baseline. However, no statistically significant differences were observed between other time points.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetes patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance training and/or HMB administration would improve physical function, muscle strength, and quality of life in medical ICU patients.
results_summary: Resistance training and combination treatment groups showed significant improvements in physical function (SPPB scores and 6MWD) and muscle strength (MRC and grip strength), but no significant changes were observed in muscle mass, quality of life, or 60-day mortality. The HMB group alone did not show significant improvements.
population_specificity: Adult patients with internal medical diagnoses admitted to the ICU.
effective_dosage: HMB group received 3 g/day of HMBCa.
study_duration: From ICU admission to hospital discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and safety of a clinical trial comparing usual care physiotherapy (including walking) to physiotherapy plus non-invasive ventilation for treating hypoxaemia after major abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The study assessed the feasibility of the trial design and safety of interventions, including walking as part of usual care, but did not report specific efficacy outcomes for walking alone. Secondary outcomes included treatment adherence and exploratory measures like postoperative activity levels.
population_specificity: Adults with hypoxaemia within 72 hours of major abdominal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, feasibility, and timing of gait training with body-weight support (BWS) in neurological ICU patients.
results_summary: The study found that BWS walking was safe and generally well tolerated, with minor adverse events that resolved spontaneously. Most patients showed small hemodynamic, respiratory, and pain parameter changes, and the median time to unsuspended walking was 11 days after BWS initiation.
population_specificity: Adults with neurological injuries requiring mechanical ventilation in a neuroICU.
effective_dosage: Median session duration was 31 minutes, with a median walking distance of 17 meters per session.
study_duration: One-year observational study, with a median of 2 BWS sessions per patient (max 10).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) on pain, walking capacity, functional status, and quality of life in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: Active tDCS showed sustained analgesic effects for 3 months post-treatment, improved asymptomatic walking distance and duration, and enhanced quality of life, particularly in pain, physical functioning, and general health. Functional status improvements were mainly observed at 1 month.
population_specificity: 32 patients with chronic lower extremity pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
effective_dosage: 10 consecutive weekdays (10 sessions) of tDCS over the motor cortex contralateral to the painful lower extremity.
study_duration: 10 days of intervention, with follow-ups at post-session, 1 month, and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of cemented versus uncemented stem fixation on gait patterns in patients who underwent total hip arthroplasty (THA) due to femoral neck fractures.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in temporospatial gait parameters or abduction-adduction motions between cemented and uncemented stems, but patients with cemented stems showed increased hip flexion and reduced extension. The altered gait pattern persisted 2 years post-operation, suggesting it may be due to the implant or surgical trauma rather than degenerative disease.
population_specificity: 45 patients who underwent THA due to acute femoral neck fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two resistance training programs with equated power but differing load intensities on older adults' functionality, strength, and cardiovascular endurance, including walking performance.
results_summary: Both training groups improved functional performance, but only the high-load low-velocity group showed significant improvement in 6-minute walking performance (pre: 514.3 ± 89.0 m, post: 552.6 ± 65.4 m; p < 0.05). The control group experienced a decline in global power performance for some exercises.
population_specificity: Forty-four active older adults (66.3 ± 4.5 years, 23 female).
effective_dosage: Resistance training at 95% of individual peak power, twice weekly for 5 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of enzyme replacement therapies, including their impact on walking ability (measured via the six-minute walk test), in people with late-onset Pompe disease.
results_summary: Alglucosidase alfa probably improves walking distance (6MWT) compared to placebo, and avalglucosidase alfa likely improves it further compared to alglucosidase alfa. Other combinations showed uncertain or minimal effects on walking outcomes.
population_specificity: People with late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD) of any age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if gait variability in real-world settings could objectively identify fatigue and daytime sleepiness, compared to subjective patient-reported outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that gait variability measures had modest accuracy (highest 57.04%) in classifying fatigue and sleepiness, with weak correlations (strongest 0.262). TGV measures performed worse than other approaches.
population_specificity: 159 participants (117 with immune/neurodegenerative disorders, 42 healthy controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether wearable device data (e.g., Fitbit) could provide more granular and objective measures of disability progression in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients compared to standard clinical scales.
results_summary: The study found that MS patients with confirmed disability progression had approximately 1392 fewer daily steps than stable patients, but the decrease in steps over time was not significantly different between the two groups. Similar results were observed for disability progression defined by walking tests (6MWT and T25FW).
population_specificity: 400 MS patients (mean age 45.6 years, 67% female) recruited for a longitudinal multicenter observational study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation fidelity and participant engagement of outdoor walking interventions for older adults with difficulty walking outdoors.
results_summary: The study found high implementation fidelity and participant engagement in the workshop and walking sessions, though attendance in the outdoor walk group was modest (64% attended >50% of sessions). Participants who attended were active and engaged during sessions.
population_specificity: Older adults with difficulty walking outdoors.
effective_dosage: Outdoor walk group met 2x/week for 10 weeks; weekly reminders group received phone reminders 1x/week for 10 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify musculoskeletal loads during SCBA carriage in firefighters and evaluate the impact of shoulder strap length variation on injury prevention.
results_summary: Walking with SCBA increased rectus femoris force and hip reaction force by 34.92%, indicating heightened musculoskeletal load. Shoulder strap length variation influenced low back pain risk, suggesting ergonomic adjustments may mitigate injury.
population_specificity: Twelve firefighters (height: 174.6 ± 2.4 cm, mass: 67 ± 3.5 kg, BMI = 22 ± 1 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of proprioception training (PT) and core stability training (CST) on gait parameters in deaf adolescents over an 8-week period.
results_summary: PT significantly improved all gait parameters, while CST improved only gait velocity and cadence. PT was found to have a greater overall effect on gait parameters compared to CST.
population_specificity: Deaf adolescents (20 participants) and typically developing adolescents (11 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility and acceptability of a smartphone-based safety plan, including the use of walking as an internal coping strategy for patients with a history of recent suicidal behavior.
results_summary: Walking was the most commonly reported internal coping strategy used by patients in the safety plan. The study found high participation rates and high acceptability, with overall satisfaction scores indicating positive reception of the intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with a history of recent suicidal behavior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of regular exercise, particularly walking, on heart rate variability (HRV) in individuals with lower extremity arterial disease (LEAD) and claudication symptoms.
results_summary: Walking training showed some positive effects on HRV, including increased parasympathetic modulation and decreased sympathetic modulation in a subset of studies, but the overall evidence was weak and inconsistent. The study highlighted the need for standardized methodologies in future HRV research.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower extremity arterial disease (LEAD) and claudication symptoms (66% male, aged 61-68 years, ankle brachial index: 0.4-0.7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the evidence for the application of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) in the recovery of gait disturbance in stroke patients.
results_summary: Moderate to low-quality evidence suggested a beneficial but non-significant effect of tDCS on gait parameters such as walking speed, mobility, endurance, and motor function. However, the evidence was insufficient to strongly recommend tDCS for gait recovery.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with gait disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of virtual reality-assisted gait adaptation training versus overground gait adaptation training on balance and walking in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking speed, obstacle avoidance ability, Timed Up and Go test, and postural stability in the virtual reality group, but no significant differences in other balance measures or the Barthel Index.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (n=54, divided into two groups of 27 each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effect of a 'sit less, move more, sleep better' program early after stroke on functional mobility and global disability outcomes, while exploring imaging and behavioural markers influencing walking recovery.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it aims to assess changes in functional mobility, walking endurance, gait speed, and quality of life through a structured movement program compared to usual care. Results will be analyzed using mixed-effects models and compositional associations between movement-related behaviours and outcomes.
population_specificity: 50 patients with acute ischemic stroke within 7 days of symptom onset, aged 18 or older, with ongoing walking goals.
effective_dosage: Up to 1 hour/day, 5 days/week for 6 weeks.
study_duration: 6 weeks (intervention), with follow-up at 6 and 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 12-week technology-assisted cardiac rehabilitation (TACR) intervention, including walking, on health outcomes in coronary heart disease (CHD) patients with central obesity.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in daily steps at six weeks, reduced weekly sitting minutes, increased total exercise, and better health-promoting behaviors, self-efficacy, and anthropometric measures (BMI and waist circumference) at 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Coronary heart disease patients with central obesity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pedometer used for daily step tracking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect and safety of combining pharmacopuncture therapy and acupotomy with Conventional Korean Medicine Treatments (CKMT) for lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. Outcomes will include changes in pain (VAS), walking distance, and quality of life measures over 14 weeks.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
study_duration: 6 weeks of treatment, with follow-up to 14 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of CCT (Circuit Class Training) in improving mobility and walking capacity in post-stroke rehabilitation.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 17 trials with 1297 participants demonstrated that CCT effectively improves walking capacity and supports mobility post-stroke, leading to greater independence in daily activities.
population_specificity: Individuals who have experienced a stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of dance and rhythmic auditory stimulation (RAS) on balance, gait, and walking in individuals with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: Preliminary evidence suggests dance and RAS improve body functions, particularly balance, gait, walking, and cardiorespiratory fitness in CP patients. Research gaps remain, especially in participation and environmental domains.
population_specificity: Children and adults with cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of supervised walking rehabilitation in the management of lower-extremity arterial disease (LEAD), particularly in patients with diabetes.
results_summary: The study highlights that supervised walking rehabilitation is crucial in LEAD management, alongside other lifestyle interventions like smoking cessation and healthy diet. However, the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data on walking, focusing more on broader therapeutic strategies.
population_specificity: Patients with lower-extremity arterial disease, particularly those with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a biomechanical therapy involving a foot-worn device during walking improves outcomes after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The biomechanical therapy group showed significant improvements in pain, function, knee scores, and walking distance compared to the control group, along with healthier gait patterns at 1 year post-surgery.
population_specificity: 50 patients who underwent unilateral TKA.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking protocol with a biomechanical or sham device).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of walking-based supervised exercise therapy and step-monitored exercise for improving functional outcomes in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: Supervised exercise therapy is ideal for intermittent claudication, while step-monitored exercise can increase walking performance and compliance with less staff supervision. Walking-based interventions are effective but face barriers to clinical implementation.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), particularly those with intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review clinical and molecular data on WWOX-related disorders, particularly WOREE syndrome, and describe phenotype/genotype correlations.
results_summary: The study found that WOREE syndrome is a severe epileptic encephalopathy characterized by absence of language development and inability to walk, early-onset drug-resistant seizures, ophthalmological involvement, and high likelihood of premature death. The most severe clinical presentation was associated with null genotypes.
population_specificity: Patients with WOREE syndrome and biallelic pathogenic variants in the WWOX gene (20 additional patients from 18 unrelated families).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of yoga versus walking (control group) on body composition and sleep quality in obese males over a 14-week intervention and 3-month follow-up.
results_summary: The control group (walking) showed no significant improvements in body composition or sleep quality compared to the yoga group, and some gains from the intervention period were lost during follow-up.
population_specificity: Obese males in an urban setting (control group: n = 35, age 42.20 ± 12.06).
effective_dosage: Walking for 1.5 hours daily, 5 days a week.
study_duration: 14 weeks of intervention, followed by a 3-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether surgical or conservative treatment is more effective for improving walking ability in patients with cervical spinal cord injury (CSCI) without major bone injury.
results_summary: The study found that 35 of 63 patients improved to walk at 6 months post-injury. Patients with spinal cord compression ≥33.2% showed better motor recovery after surgery, while conservative treatment was generally recommended unless specific conditions (e.g., high compression and low ISMG grade) were met.
population_specificity: Patients with cervical spinal cord injury (CSCI) without major bone injury (Frankel A-C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical utility, validity, and reliability of outcome measures and tools used to quantify lower limb changes in children with idiopathic toe walking (ITW).
results_summary: The review identified 27 different measurement tools, with limited reliability and validity reporting. The Alvarez classification tool combined with the Vicon motion system was noted as a contemporary choice for describing ITW gait, but no significant associations were found between common assessments.
population_specificity: Children diagnosed with idiopathic toe walking (ITW).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate prosthetic rehabilitation interventions for walking in older dysvascular individuals with unilateral transfemoral or transgenicular amputation.
results_summary: The study found no adverse effects from prosthetic weight adjustments, with participants showing varied preferences for different weights (150 g, 770 g, or 1625 g). However, the evidence was of very low quality and insufficient to inform optimal prosthetic rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Older dysvascular individuals (aged 60+ years) with unilateral transfemoral amputation.
effective_dosage: Prosthetic weights of 150 g, 770 g, and 1625 g.

study_goal: To examine the influence of prenatal exercise, including walking, on reducing depression and anxiety during pregnancy and the postpartum period.
results_summary: The study found that exercise-only interventions, which likely included walking, reduced the severity of prenatal depressive symptoms, but exercise combined with other cointerventions did not show the same effect. The meta-analysis indicated a moderate reduction in prenatal depression with exercise.
population_specificity: Pregnant women without contraindication to exercise.

study_goal: The researchers were not studying Walking; the study focused on the effects of Robuvit® supplementation in individuals with PTSD.
results_summary: The study did not evaluate Walking; it found that Robuvit® supplementation reduced PTSD symptoms and oxidative stress compared to standard management alone.
population_specificity: Otherwise healthy individuals with PTSD following major earthquakes in Central Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of three types of physical training programs (treadmill walking, Nordic walking, and combined resistance and Nordic walking) in improving walking distance and lower-limb strength in patients with chronic lower-limb arterial insufficiency.
results_summary: Combined resistance and Nordic walking training (RES+NW) was more effective than Nordic walking alone or treadmill walking alone in improving ankle force-velocity parameters and walking distance, particularly in the 6 Minute Walk Test (6MWT). All training programs increased walking distance, with stronger lower limbs correlating to longer walking distances.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic lower-limb arterial insufficiency and intermittent claudication.
effective_dosage: Supervised motor rehabilitation three times a week.
